{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3425274,"name":"","username":"Robotgobrrrr","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/robotgobrrrr/{size}/238076_2.png","created_at":"2024-09-19T16:53:28.289Z","cooked":"

Have any teams had success using color pipelines vs the neural nets for game piece alignment on limelight? Our LL3 with a neural net gets 15 fps and seems to have quite a bit of latency, which forced us to lower our centerline approach speed significantly when aligning to a note in auto. Playing with a LL2+ yesterday I was getting 90 fps with a color pipeline that was tracking a note really well. I’m guessing the neural net would be more robust to lighting or color variations, but 6x the frame rate would definitely help us with high speed game piece alignment. We also had a lot of issues with the coral disconnecting and rebooting the LL, but that was supposedly fixed in a LL software update. Even still removing the coral as a failure point would be a win for us on reliability.

Has anyone had much success with color pipelines in competition?
We’re also considering photonvision for game piece detection but worried about reliability for something we rely heavily on.

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":11,"updated_at":"2024-09-19T16:53:46.792Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":6,"reads":242,"readers_count":241,"score":108.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":471476,"topic_slug":"color-pipelines-vs-neural-net","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":57453,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/color-pipelines-vs-neural-net/471476/1","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3425306,"name":"Roman A.","username":"RomanTechPlus","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/romantechplus/{size}/214929_2.png","created_at":"2024-09-19T17:50:52.120Z","cooked":"

If you’re worried about reliability, Photonvision’s NN pipeline is absolutely the way to go. It will be far more robust to color and lighting changes in addion to being substantially superior in regards to avoiding false positives (like you’d have with a color pipeline and any orange (or close enough to orange) colored blob of sufficient size).

Lead"},"post_url":"/t/color-pipelines-vs-neural-net/471476/2","custom_user_title":"5104 BreakerBots | Software and Additive Mfg. Lead","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3425495,"name":"","username":"AvocadoPeel","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/avocadopeel/{size}/232401_2.png","created_at":"2024-09-20T13:59:18.297Z","cooked":"

If you watch 2056’s behind the bumpers, you can see they use a color pipeline for note detection. If it’s reliable enough for Tyler Holtzman then I’d say it’s reliable enough.

I will also say that the latency and low fps of the Limelight neural net pipeline isn’t a huge deal breaker, we used it to great effect at our most recent competition. We also switched back and forth in season, and had equal issues and success with both.

The camera mount angle is also a big factor in a color pipeline, as tracking a circular target is less prone to false positives; if the mount position is low and you only see the side of the note there can be issues. You can see in 2056’s behind the bumpers video they see the note from a high angle.

I believe 4678 uses a color pipeline. They have powerful headlights to get consistent color of the objects.

At our competition we were streaming video back to the DS laptop which ran a ML model for cargo detection on the laptop’s GPU. It worked surprisingly well, the latency wasn’t that bad and it could handle 40fps, but a last minute hardware change broke it for competition unfortunately. We did get it to work at home which was pretty cool, and the model was accurate enough that it could detect red cargo on a red wall across the field at 320x240, and the same for blue.

If you decide to train your own model like we did, I recommend going to a week 0 practice competition and just recording the stream from all your cameras on your DS computer, that way you can collect TONS of image data from your camera’s perspective and at its resolution in a real match scenario that you can then label and train the model on. That’s what we did and we improved our model accuracy drastically.

I believe the reliability of color detection heavily depends on the specific game pieces, which are still unknown for next season. If next year’s game includes multiple or smaller game pieces, this will likely influence the accuracy of color detection.

During the season, my team implemented CUDA-accelerated object detection that runs on the Jetson Nano, capable of 720p at 50fps. Team 8814 used the Jetson Orin in the off-season, and I think their programmer, @Geoffrey8814, can provide more information. I heard it was successful, potentially achieving 720p at 90fps with two cameras simultaneously. If you’re concerned about performance, consider using a better co-processor.

The cost is a little higher, though:

  • 720p 120fps USB webcam + Jetson Orin Nano = $650
  • Limelight 3A + Google Coral Accelerator = $475

Your methods will probably work even better with the new radio, which offers higher bandwidth and a more consistent connection.

","post_number":8,"post_type":1,"posts_count":11,"updated_at":"2024-09-22T13:16:16.201Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":5,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":63,"readers_count":62,"score":12.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":471476,"topic_slug":"color-pipelines-vs-neural-net","display_username":"sam liu","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":67786,"username":"wisplite","name":"","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/w/ec9cab/{size}.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":60033,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"CE Student @ UWaterloo | 5516 Alum "},"post_url":"/t/color-pipelines-vs-neural-net/471476/8","custom_user_title":"CE Student @ UWaterloo | 5516 Alum ","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3426064,"name":"Geoffrey","username":"Geoffrey8814","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/geoffrey8814/{size}/262430_2.png","created_at":"2024-09-22T14:18:00.093Z","cooked":"

If you are using it for alignment, the color pipeline works well. We utilized a color pipeline based on Limelight 3 for our season robot. The only problem we faced was that it sometimes detected notes behind the source. We managed to detect notes within 3 meters(10 feet). However, the color pipeline can be susceptible if you don’t tune it well. As @catrix has mentioned, we utilized Jetson Orin Nano for object detection using YOLOv8n with a custom dataset. The input size is 640x640. We have two cameras, both running object detection and pose estimation pipelines. Due to memory limitations, we capped the fps at 50. The primary benefit of ML object detection is its stability for note detection and typically extended detection range (depending on your dataset). We implemented it to detect another robot on the field. Another advantage of ML object detection is the ability to implement a tracker. If you are interested in more advanced object detection, you can explore a vision transformer.

Here is our code:

github.com
